title: Martin Luther King, Jr.: "I have a dream"

multiple-choice.question: Who is the speaker of the famous speech in the transcript?
What event is Martin Luther King Jr. referring to as "the greatest demonstration for freedom in the history of our nation"?

options.label: A
options.text: The signing of the Emancipation Proclamation

options.label: D
options.text: The end of the Civil War

multiple-choice.question: According to Martin Luther King Jr., what is the current state of the Negro in America, 100 years after the Emancipation Proclamation?

options.label: A
options.text: They are completely free and equal

options.label: B
options.text: They are still facing segregation and discrimination

options.label: C
options.text: They are slowly gaining their rights

options.label: D
options.text: They are no longer living in poverty

multiple-choice.question: What is the "promissory note" that Martin Luther King Jr. refers to in his speech?

options.label: D
options.text: A promise of freedom and equality for all Americans

multiple-choice.question: According to Martin Luther King Jr., what is the current state of the "bank of justice" in America?

options.label: D
options.text: It is not relevant to the current situation

multiple-choice.question: What is the "fierce urgency of now" that Martin Luther King Jr. refers to in his speech?

options.label: A
options.text: The need to wait patiently for change

options.label: B
options.text: The need to take immediate action for civil rights

options.label: C
options.text: The need to compromise on civil rights

options.label: D
options.text: The need to ignore the current situation

multiple-choice.question: According to Martin Luther King Jr., what will happen if the nation returns to "business as usual" after the March on Washington?

options.label: A
options.text: The Negro will be satisfied and stop protesting

options.label: B
options.text: The nation will experience a period of peace and tranquility

options.label: C
options.text: The whirlwinds of revolt will continue to shake the foundations of the nation

options.label: D
options.text: The Negro will lose their rights and freedoms

multiple-choice.question: What is Martin Luther King Jr.'s dream for the future of America?

options.label: A
options.text: A nation where the Negro is superior to the white man

options.label: B
options.text: A nation where the Negro is separate from the white man

options.label: C
options.text: A nation where all men are created equal and judged by the content of their character

options.label: D
options.text: A nation where the Negro is still facing segregation and discrimination

multiple-choice.question: According to Martin Luther King Jr., what will happen when freedom rings from every mountain side?

options.label: A
options.text: The nation will be divided and separated

options.label: B
options.text: The Negro will be satisfied and stop protesting

options.label: C
options.text: All of God's children will be able to sing with new meaning and be free at last

options.label: D
options.text: The nation will experience a period of war and conflict

multiple-choice.question: What is the final phrase of Martin Luther King Jr.'s speech, which is repeated several times?

options.label: D
options.text: "Free at last, free at last, thank God Almighty we are free at last"

title: How to build a fictional world - Kate Messner

multiple-choice.question: In J.R.R.'s world, how many wizards were sent by the Valar to guide the inhabitants of Middle Earth?
What is unique about Gandalf's body and spirit in Middle Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Both his body and spirit are mortal

options.label: B
options.text: Both his body and spirit are immortal

options.label: C
options.text: His body is immortal, but his spirit is mortal

options.label: D
options.text: His body is mortal, but his spirit is immortal

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the answer to the ultimate question of life, the universe, and everything?
What is the key to making intricate fictional worlds believable and comprehensible?

options.label: C
options.text: Consistency within a spectrum of physical and societal rules

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of authors of science fiction and fantasy in building worlds?

options.label: A
options.text: They only create characters and stories

options.label: B
options.text: They only create rules and maps

options.label: C
options.text: They literally build worlds, making rules, maps, lineages, languages, cultures, universes, and alternate universes

options.label: D
options.text: They only create universes and alternate universes

multiple-choice.question: What is the starting point for building a fictional world, according to the author?

options.label: B
options.text: Brainstorming answers to questions about the world

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of creating a timeline in building a fictional world?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine the rules of society

options.label: B
options.text: To decide on the government of the world

options.label: C
options.text: To show how the world came to be and what past events have shaped it

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the aspects of day-to-day life that the author considers when building a fictional world?

options.label: A
options.text: Only the weather and living arrangements

options.label: C
options.text: The weather, living arrangements, food, entertainment, relationships with animals and plants, technology, transportation, communication, and access to information

options.label: D
options.text: Only the government and rules of society

multiple-choice.question: What is the next step after building a fictional world, according to the author?

options.label: A
options.text: To set the characters free in the world and see what happens

multiple-choice.question: What question should the author ask themselves to determine the story that will emerge from the world they created?

options.label: A
options.text: How does this world shape the individuals who live in it, and what kind of conflict is likely to emerge?

options.label: B
options.text: What is the purpose of this world?

options.label: C
options.text: How can I make this world more interesting?

options.label: D
options.text: What is the theme of this world?

title: How sugar affects the brain - Nicole Avena

multiple-choice.question: What is the general term used to describe a class of molecules called carbohydrates?

What happens when sugar hits your tongue?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect food that's gone bad and to ensure variety in our diet

options.label: B
options.text: To detect food that's high in sugar and to avoid it

options.label: C
options.text: To detect food that's low in fat and to prefer it

options.label: D
options.text: To detect food that's high in protein and to prioritize it

options.label: B
options.text: It behaves like a drug, continuing to feel rewarding

options.label: C
options.text: It behaves like a toxin, causing harm and damage

options.label: D
options.text: It behaves like a fiber, promoting digestion and satiety

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because sugar is abundant among dopamine-inducing foods

options.label: C
options.text: Because sugar behaves like a drug, continuing to feel rewarding

options.label: D
options.text: Because sugar is a necessary nutrient for our bodies

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of overconsumption of sugar on the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: It has no effect on the brain

options.label: B
options.text: It has a positive effect on the brain, improving cognitive function

options.label: C
options.text: It has an addictive effect on the brain, leading to cravings and overconsumption

options.label: D
options.text: It has a toxic effect on the brain, causing damage and harm

title: Should we eat bugs? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the practice of consuming bugs as a food source?

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It can uplift people through small-scale, productive farms

options.label: D

title: The death of the universe

multiple-choice.question: What type of scientist studies the end of the universe?
According to Einstein's Theory of General Relativity, what are the possible shapes of the universe?

options.label: D
options.text: Positively curved, negatively curved, or flat

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the universe's energy density is made up of ordinary or baryonic matter?
What is dark matter, and how does it interact with light?

options.label: A
options.text: Dark matter is a type of ordinary matter that interacts strongly with light.

options.label: B
options.text: Dark matter is a type of matter that interacts weakly with light and behaves like ordinary matter.

options.label: C
options.text: Dark matter is a type of energy that interacts strongly with light.

options.label: D
options.text: Dark matter is a type of energy that interacts weakly with light and behaves like ordinary energy.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the universe's energy density is made up of dark matter?
What is dark energy, and how does it behave?

options.label: A
options.text: Dark energy is a type of matter that behaves like ordinary matter.

options.label: B
options.text: Dark energy is a type of energy that behaves like anti-gravity force.

options.label: C
options.text: Dark energy is a type of matter that behaves like anti-gravity force.

options.label: D
options.text: Dark energy is a type of energy that behaves like ordinary matter.

multiple-choice.question: What is the leading idea for dark energy?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a type of ordinary matter.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a type of dark matter.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a type of energy that behaves like ordinary energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the predicted fate of the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: The universe will collapse in on itself.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe will continue to expand and eventually become cold and empty.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe will remain in a steady state.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe will undergo a new Big Bang.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is considered one of the most commonly detested pests in the world?

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: The energy level of the electrons

options.label: D
options.text: The type of bond being formed

options.label: D
options.text: Only the electrons in the nucleus

What is the primary force holding molecules together?

title: How art can help you analyze - Amy E. Herman

multiple-choice.question: What is a common misconception about art in the real world?

options.label: C
options.text: By increasing our knowledge of history.

title: Kabuki: The people's dramatic art - Amanda Mattes

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the word "Kabuki" in Japanese culture?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of traditional Japanese dance

options.label: B
options.text: A style of Japanese theater performance

options.label: C
options.text: A Japanese verb meaning "out of the ordinary or bizarre"

options.label: D
options.text: A type of traditional Japanese music

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with starting the Kabuki tradition in early 17th century Kyoto?

options.label: B
options.text: A shrine maiden named Izumo no Okuni

multiple-choice.question: What was unique about Kabuki compared to the upper-class dance theater form known as Noh?

options.label: A
options.text: Kabuki used masks instead of makeup

options.label: B
options.text: Kabuki focused on folk tales instead of historical events

options.label: C
options.text: Kabuki relied on makeup and facial expressions instead of masks

options.label: D
options.text: Kabuki was only performed by upper-class individuals

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the all-female version of Kabuki that emerged in the early 17th century?

options.label: A
options.text: It was deemed too expensive to produce

options.label: B
options.text: It was considered too risqué and immoral

options.label: C
options.text: It was seen as a threat to traditional Japanese values

options.label: D
options.text: It was not popular enough among the general public

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the ban on Onna-Kabuki and Wakashu-Kabuki?

options.label: B
options.text: Kabuki was only performed by women

options.label: C
options.text: Kabuki transitioned to Yaro-Kabuki, performed by men

options.label: D
options.text: Kabuki became a form of puppet theater

options.label: A
options.text: Kabuki became more spontaneous and improvisational

options.label: B
options.text: Kabuki became more structured and formalized

options.label: C
options.text: Kabuki became more focused on historical events

options.label: D
options.text: Kabuki became less popular among the general public

multiple-choice.question: How did the Meiji Restoration of 1868 affect Kabuki?

options.label: B
options.text: Kabuki became more isolated from Western influences

options.label: C
options.text: Kabuki underwent significant changes and experimentation

options.label: D
options.text: Kabuki became less popular among the Japanese public

multiple-choice.question: How did Kabuki influence Western artists such as Claude Monet and Vincent van Gogh?

options.label: A
options.text: They were inspired by Kabuki's use of masks and costumes

options.label: B
options.text: They were influenced by Kabuki's focus on historical events

options.label: C
options.text: They incorporated Kabuki elements into their own work

options.label: D
options.text: They were not influenced by Kabuki at all

multiple-choice.question: What is the current status of Kabuki in Japanese culture?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a dying art form with little popularity

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Light waves, visible and invisible

multiple-choice.question: What is light considered to be in terms of its behavior?

options.label: C
options.text: Both a wave and a particle

options.label: D
options.text: Neither a wave nor a particle

multiple-choice.question: What determines the size of a wave?

What determines the energy of light?
Why can humans only see a specific range of light?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our eyes are sensitive to all wavelengths

options.label: B
options.text: Because our retina is only sensitive to a specific range of energies

options.label: C
options.text: Because light with other wavelengths is too intense

options.label: D
options.text: Because light with other wavelengths is too weak

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Neither rods nor cones measure color or brightness

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: It stimulates the retina but is not perceived

multiple-choice.question: What makes one kind of light different from another?

options.label: B
options.text: With special detectors or digital eyes

options.label: C
options.text: With telescopes that only detect visible light

options.label: D
options.text: With microscopes that only detect visible light

multiple-choice.question: Why is it useful to study the light from distant stars or galaxies?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it allows us to understand the physics of light on Earth

options.label: D

title: What are stem cells? - Craig A. Kohn

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of scientists and doctors researching stem cells in the context of personalized medicine?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a universal cure for all diseases

options.label: B
options.text: To develop medicine that is tailored to an individual's specific needs

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the cost of medical treatment

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the effectiveness of current treatments

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about stem cells compared to other cells in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a specific job or function

options.label: B
options.text: They are only found in certain tissues

options.label: C
options.text: They have the potential to become all other kinds of cells in the body

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used for regenerative medicine

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how the body uses stem cells to replace worn-out cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Replacing the lining of the lungs every year

options.label: B
options.text: Replacing the lining of the intestines every four days

options.label: C
options.text: Replacing the lining of the stomach every month

options.label: D
options.text: Replacing the lining of the skin every week

multiple-choice.question: What is regenerative medicine, and how does it relate to stem cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Regenerative medicine is the use of stem cells to replace damaged bodily tissue

options.label: B
options.text: Regenerative medicine is the use of stem cells to create new organs

options.label: C
options.text: Regenerative medicine is the use of stem cells to treat blood diseases

options.label: D
options.text: Regenerative medicine is the use of stem cells to understand how the body works

multiple-choice.question: What is leukemia, and how is it related to stem cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Leukemia is a form of cancer that affects the brain, and stem cells are used to treat it

options.label: B
options.text: Leukemia is a form of cancer that affects the bone marrow, and stem cells are used to treat it

options.label: C
options.text: Leukemia is a form of cancer that affects the lungs, and stem cells are used to treat it

options.label: D
options.text: Leukemia is a form of cancer that affects the skin, and stem cells are used to treat it

multiple-choice.question: What are the three types of stem cells mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Adult stem cells, embryonic stem cells, and induced pluripotent stem cells

options.label: B
options.text: Adult stem cells, tissue-specific stem cells, and embryonic stem cells

options.label: C
options.text: Embryonic stem cells, induced pluripotent stem cells, and blood stem cells

options.label: D
options.text: Adult stem cells, blood stem cells, and tissue-specific stem cells

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about embryonic stem cells compared to other types of stem cells?

options.label: A
options.text: They are only found in adult tissues

options.label: B
options.text: They are pluripotent, meaning they can become any kind of tissue in the body

options.label: C
options.text: They are only used for regenerative medicine

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used to treat blood diseases

multiple-choice.question: What are induced pluripotent stem cells, and how are they created?

options.label: A
options.text: Induced pluripotent stem cells are created from leftover embryos and are pluripotent

options.label: B
options.text: Induced pluripotent stem cells are created from regular skin, fat, liver, or other cells that scientists have changed to behave like embryonic stem cells

options.label: C
options.text: Induced pluripotent stem cells are created from adult stem cells and are used to treat blood diseases

options.label: D
options.text: Induced pluripotent stem cells are created from embryonic stem cells and are used for regenerative medicine

multiple-choice.question: How can scientists use stem cells to understand how the body works?

options.label: A
options.text: By watching stem cells develop into tissue to understand the mechanisms that the body uses to create new tissue

options.label: B
options.text: By using stem cells to treat blood diseases

options.label: C
options.text: By using stem cells to replace damaged bodily tissue

options.label: D
options.text: By using stem cells to create new organs

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of stem cell research in the context of personalized medicine?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop a universal cure for all diseases

options.label: B
options.text: To create a very special kind of personalized medicine in which we could replace your own body parts with your own body parts

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the cost of medical treatment

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the effectiveness of current treatments

title: Origins of religion

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary way Stone Age people learned about the world around them?
How did Stone Age people view the universe and their place in it?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed the universe was vast and they were insignificant

options.label: B
options.text: They believed the universe was flat, small, and they were at the center

options.label: C
options.text: They believed the universe was round and they were on the periphery

options.label: D
options.text: They believed the universe was unknown and they were explorers

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe would happen if they ate the flesh of a strong beast?

options.label: B
options.text: They would acquire the spirit of the beast

multiple-choice.question: How did Stone Age people view the movement of objects in the world?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed movement was the result of natural laws

options.label: B
options.text: They believed movement was the result of will and spirit

options.label: C
options.text: They believed movement was the result of chance and randomness

options.label: D
options.text: They believed movement was the result of human intervention

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe was the nature of the spirits they saw in the world?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed spirits were separate from materiality

options.label: B
options.text: They believed spirits were a part of materiality

options.label: C
options.text: They believed spirits were only found in living things

options.label: D
options.text: They believed spirits were only found in non-living things

multiple-choice.question: How did Stone Age people view the concept of death and the afterlife?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed the spirit left the body at death and went to an invisible world

options.label: B
options.text: They believed the spirit stayed with the body after death

options.label: C
options.text: They believed there was no afterlife

options.label: D
options.text: They believed the afterlife was a physical place

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary purpose of storytelling in Stone Age societies?

options.label: A
options.text: To entertain and pass the time

options.label: B
options.text: To explain the world and its workings

multiple-choice.question: How did Stone Age people view the concept of magic and its relationship to the gods?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed magic was separate from the gods

options.label: B
options.text: They believed magic was a manifestation of the gods' power

options.label: C
options.text: They believed magic was a human invention

options.label: D
options.text: They believed magic was a natural phenomenon

multiple-choice.question: What was the earliest form of religious ritual in Stone Age societies?
How did Stone Age people view the concept of social progress and human capabilities?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed in the possibility of social progress and human improvement

options.label: B
options.text: They believed the world would always be as the gods had made it

options.label: C
options.text: They believed humans had the power to change the world

options.label: D
options.text: They believed humans were limited by their biology
